Communicative NGOMSL: Development of an Evaluation Method for a Text-Based Communication System

Sangwon Lee Louisiana State University , Baton RougeCorrespondencesangwon.advance@gmail.com
 & Richard J. Koubek Louisiana State University , Baton Rouge
Pages 1013-1036
Accepted author version posted online: 30 Jun 2011
Published online:30 Sep 2011

            Articles

            Communicative NGOMSL: Development of an Evaluation Method for a Text-Based Communication System

            • Full Article
            • Figures & data
            • References
            • Citations
            • Metrics
            • Reprints & Permissions
            • PDF

            Abstract

            Goals, Operators, Methods, and Selection rules (GOMS) is an analytic method and a model evaluation method for the knowledge necessary for a user to perform tasks in a system, and Natural GOMS Language (NGOMSL), a version of GOMS, is an attempt to define a language so that the GOMS model can be precisely constructed in a structured way. This study proposes Communicative NGOMSL, which is an extension of NGOMSL intended to accommodate modeling of text-based communication among two or more individuals. Besides the properties of GOMS techniques in evaluation, Communicative NGOMSL additionally considers common ground and communication time: Common ground refers to the mutual knowledge, beliefs, and assumptions of participants in communication, and communication time refers to the time that an individual waits for another to respond. The analysis of a Communicative NGOMSL model provides some information for a common task goal in a text-based communication system: (a) the relationship between the grounding process and Communicative NGOMSL statements, (b) the ratio of communication time to execution time for each individual, and (c) the balance among individuals in terms of learning time and mental workload. A demonstration of Communicative NGOMSL is provided through a sample case—a virtual text-based chat tool for exchanging addresses between two individuals. Future work needed to address the limitations of this study and further develop Communicative NGOMSL is discussed.

            1. INTRODUCTION

            Collaboration through computer-based systems has become a common phenomenon as computer technologies have developed. Since the term computer-supported cooperative work (CSCW) was first introduced at a workshop in 1984 (Grudin, 1994), many researchers have studied the relationships between computer systems and people's collaborative activities and coordination in various settings. CSCW refers to both (a) a computer-based system that supports people in a group to effectively achieve common task goals and provides an interface in shared environments (Ellis, Gibbs, & Rein, 1991) and (b) the use of such a system for group communication (Kies, Williges, & Rosson, 1998). CSCW research has mainly focused on understanding the characteristics of group work as they have been applied to the development of computer-based technologies supporting cooperative work. Computer-mediated communication (CMC) is a part of CSCW. According to Santra and Giri (2009), CMC is “a generic term that incorporates all forms of communications between individuals and among groups via networked computers” (p. 103). CMC with a common goal is a cooperative work among two or more persons. With the recent rapid changes in computer technology of CMC, social networking over the Internet has become popular.

            To improve cooperative work and communication, it is essential to evaluate CMC systems. Analysis methods for CMC systems have been studied by many researchers. Fischer and Ostwald (2005) stated that CMC can be analyzed in four dimensions: spatial (across distance; e.g., Nardi & Whittaker, 2002; Olson & Olson, 2000), temporal (across time; e.g., Fischer et al., 1992; Mørch & Mehandjiev, 2000), technological (between persons and artifacts; e.g., Fischer, 1994; Terveen, 1995), and social (across different communities of practice; e.g., Fischer, 2001). However, it is difficult to consistently use these concepts to analyze CMC systems in a specific domain and generalize findings from various systems because they seem to be associated with contextual and social features that are almost impossible to identify (Grudin, 1988). Both the environment and the communication method affect the way how people communicate in social settings. For this reason, we need to limit the domain of this study to one specific system (a text-based communication system) in order to develop an evaluation method for CMC applications.

            Time and space are two important criteria in describing collaborative activities in CMC (Fischer & Ostwald, 2005). The CSCW Matrix was first introduced by Johansen (1988) and was later detailed by Baecker et al. (1995) (see Figure 1). This can be used to classify groupware systems according to the synchronicity of cooperative activities (synchronous vs. asynchronous) and the physical proximity of group members (collocated vs. remote). Although this matrix has a few weak points related to defining synchronous and asynchronous modes and categorizing recent systems such as Version Control System and Google Docs (Skaf-Molli, Ignat, Rahhal, & Molli, 2007), it is still useful for understanding the essence of the features of CSCW systems. According the CSCW Matrix, text-based communication systems (or text-based chat tools) can be included in the category “remote interactions” (synchronous and remote). This study aims to develop an evaluation method for a text-based communication system using two theories—Natural GOMS Language (NGOMSL) and common ground. Here, GOMS is a well-known usability evaluation method, where GOMS stands for Goals, Operators, Methods, and Selection rules (Kieras, 1988), and common ground is the shared knowledge, beliefs, and assumptions between individuals in conversation or collaboration (Klein, Woods, Bradshaw, Hoffman, & Feltovich, 2004; McCarthy, Miles, & Monk, 1991); see section 2 for more information. The method we propose in this study is called Communicative NGOMSL.

            Communicative NGOMSL: Development of an Evaluation Method for a Text-Based Communication System

            2. BACKGROUND OF COMMUNICATIVE NGOMSL

            Communicative NGOMSL is an extension of NGOMSL intended to accommodate modeling of text-based communication among two or more individuals. To solve the limitations of NGOMSL in evaluating CSCW or CMC systems, Communicative NGOMSL utilizes the theory of common ground.

            2.1. Usability Evaluation Methods and GOMS

            Usability is one of the most important factors in developing a product or system. It can be defined as an outcome: “the extent to which a product can be used by specified users to achieve specified goals with effectiveness, efficiency, and satisfaction in a specified context of use” (ISO, 1998). Over time, usability evaluation methods (UEMs) have been developed. UEMs have been studied from the beginning of human–computer interaction. Their goal is to make an application more usable by determining what needs to be changed or developed in that system as much as is possible in terms of time and cost. Also, UEMs have examined design attributes and user needs for products or systems as an essential process to make the application more competitive and to obtain supporting information and recommendation for the interfaces (Gould, Boies, & Lewis, 1991; Karat, 2005). UEMs can be classified by two criteria: (a) whether they use analytic methods or empirical methods (Rosson & Carroll, 2002) and (b) whether they deal with expert evaluation, model evaluation, user evaluation, or evaluation location (Hartson, Andre, & Williges, 2003).

            GOMS is an analytic method and a model evaluation method. A GOMS analysis is a description or model of the knowledge necessary for a user to perform tasks in a system (Kieras, 1988). As previously described, it describes Goals, Operators, Methods, and Selection rules in a relatively formal way to represent “how to do the intended tasks” knowledge required by a system. A goal is what a typical user wants to accomplish. A set of goals usually involves a hierarchy in which achieving a goal may require completing one or more subgoals. Operators are the actions that the user must execute to achieve a goal. The construction of a GOMS model is based on the idea of describing methods using high-level operators, which are replaced with a series of lower level operators. A method represents a sequence of steps taken to achieve a goal. A step in a method is usually composed of external operators involved with completing a subgoal. Selection rules provide criteria for choosing an appropriate route among two or more operators to take in order to reach a goal.

            2.2. NGOMSL and Its Limitations

            NGOMSL is a version of GOMS and is an attempt to define a language so that GOMS models can be precisely written down. It represents a procedure for a user to follow in order to accomplish goals in structured natural language notations (Kieras, 1988). NGOMSL inherently supports automatic analysis, unlike other evaluation techniques that are typically done by hand, such as user testing. An NGOMSL analysis is one of the most widely accepted analytical modeling methods based on the model human processor proposed by Card, Moran, and Newell (1983; Ivory & Hearst, 2001). The model human processor paradigm considers a user to be an information-processing system consisting of processors (perceptual, cognitive, and motor processors) interacting with each other in his or her memory. In other words, the model human processor perceives information (perceptual processor), processes it to form a response (cognitive processor), and responds (motor processor).

            Kieras (1988) described the assumptions and the characteristics of NGOMSL. NGOMSL basically assumes expertise without any interruption. It does not consider interrelationships between tasks and provides little information about learning, problem solving, or error handling. These assumptions are the basis of NGOMSL as a time performance model. Users with expertise in a system know about a set of possible routes and tend to select the one with the fewest number of actions to perform a task. Their choices of particular actions depend on their familiarity and expertise with specific tasks (Koubek & Mountjoy, 1991; Koubek & Salvendy, 1991). Thus, the predicted times for execution and learning in an NGOMSL model can be obtained through approximations using standard times that neither accommodate flexibility in performance nor consider time spent in correcting errors.

            The procedure for constructing an NGOMSL model is as follows (Kieras, 1988): (a) choose the top-level user's goals and methods; (b) do the following recursive procedure: draft a method to accomplish each goal, check for consistency and conformance to guidelines, and, if needed, go to the next lower level of analysis; (c) complete the analysis; and (d) check sensitivity to judgment calls and assumptions. The quantitative evaluation and the qualitative evaluation of an NGOMSL model of specific tasks in a system can be used to improve that system during the design process and provide a basis for training and reference documentation. The qualitative facets of a system interface include naturalness, completeness, cleanliness, consistency, and efficiency, and the values from the quantitative evaluation contain execution time and learning time based on operator sequences in a NGOMSL structure as well as validated time parameters for each operator (Gong, 1993; John & Kieras, 1996; Kieras, 1988). As a final step in analysis, uses of working memory are analyzed to identify a system interface imposing a high memory load on a user.

            In the recent situation in which cooperative work using a computerized system as an intermediary becomes more popular, one outstanding limitation of established GOMS techniques (including NGOMSL) is that they are applicable only to analyzing the relationship between an individual and a system and are not suitable for analyzing the interaction between a group (two or more individuals) and a CSCW or CMC system (e.g., Antunes, Ferreira, & Pino, 2006; Kieras & Santoro, 2004; Min, Koo, Chung, & Kim, 1999). The GOMS techniques have neither focused on allocating subtasks to an individual in a group nor considered the communication among individuals with a common task goal in a system (Min et al., 1999). A few studies have developed methods to evaluate the usability of CMC systems using the concepts of GOMS. Min et al. (1999) proposed an evaluation technique named Distributed GOMS (DGOMS), an extension of GOMS, where group tasks can be decomposed until individual subtasks are reached. DGOMS uses a communication operator to coordinate and evaluate individual tasks executed in parallel. For a case study, they applied DGOMS to the communication in a group of engineers in real nuclear power plant control rooms. Kieras and Santoro (2004) suggested a similar approach to a team task. As part of a large-scale project for the U.S. Navy, they used GLEAN (GOMS Language Evaluation Analysis) to evaluate interface and team structure designs for a new system. In this system, several persons with individual roles monitored a display and coordinated their actions via a shared radio communication channel. In other studies, groups of researchers (Antunes, Borges, Pino, & Carrico, 2005, 2006; Antunes, Ferreira, et al., 2006; Ferreira & Antunes, 2007) proposed a new analytic method inspired by GOMS to evaluate synchronous shared workspace design. To validate this method, they applied it to the designs of a collaborative game and a collaborative tool for negotiating software engineering requirements.

            The methods in these previous studies are related to our proposed method in concept but not in application. Communicative NGOMSL is basically based on DGOMS, which has newly considered communication operators in constructing a DGOMS model and has measured distribution of execution time and balance in physical and mental workload between individuals. Besides these properties of DGOMS, our method additionally provides the ratio of communication time to execution time for each individual and the balance degree in learning time between individuals (see sections 3.2.2 and 3.2.3 for more information). Also, our specific domain (i.e., a text-based communication system), unlike the physical control room (Min et al., 1999) or the specific systems for group tasks (e.g., Antunes, Borges, et al., 2006; Kieras & Santoro, 2004), makes possible to utilize the theory of common ground and to clarify primitive operator level and time estimates. Consequently, Communicative NGOMSL can provide the information about the relationship between the grounding process and NGOMSL statements in a model and use predefined time estimates for operators using a keyboard or a mouse as an input device. In addition, similar to the group tasks in Kieras and Santoro's (2004) and Antunes's studies (e.g., Antunes, Ferreira, et al., 2006; Ferreira & Antunes, 2007), Communicative NGOMSL in this study models a sequential (not parallel) conversation or collaboration in a system.

            2.3. Common Ground in Communicative NGOMSL

            The present study focuses on modeling tasks for a specific CMC system—a text-based communication system. Because the system is a communication mediate, it is necessary to develop a way to evaluate its interface between the human group and the system by considering the interrelationships both among individuals and between the subtasks performed by an individual participant. To overcome the limitations of GOMS techniques in the evaluation of text-based communication systems, we propose Communicative NGOMSL, a extended version of NGOMSL using Clark's contribution theory of discourse (or common ground; Clark & Schaefer, 1989) for the communication between persons to achieve a common task goal. Previously, McCarthy et al. (1991) used Clark's theory to analyze the usability of a text-based communication system. They examined two versions of a text-based synchronous messaging system (with and without a shared data space) to solve a problem related to the layout of a bank using the concepts of common ground. The experimental results showed that common ground was more difficult to establish in the public condition (with a shared data space) than in the private condition (without a shared data space). The researchers pointed out that this difficulty resulted from grounding constraints such as copresence and visibility. In our study, Clark's contribution theory of discourse is utilized in evaluating a text-based communication system.

            As described previously, common ground refers to the mutual knowledge, beliefs, and assumptions of individuals in a conversation or collaboration (Klein et al., 2004; McCarthy et al., 1991). As a conversation progresses, common ground is updated in an orderly way. A participant in communication tries to understand the others' utterances and to provide them with sufficient information about his or her understanding. Language is a collaborative activity, in which existing common ground is developed into further common ground and effective communication (Clark & Schaefer, 1989). Clark's contribution theory of discourse defines different kinds of common ground, formalizes the notion of collaborative activities, and describes the process by which common ground is developed. In electronically mediated communication (e.g., communication using a text-based chat tool), the grounding process is directly linked to the sequence in which common ground is established in a conversation (Clark & Schaefer, 1989; Monk, 2003): utterance – understanding of utterance – evidence of understanding sufficient for current purpose – understanding of evidence of understanding sufficient for current purpose – grounding criterion. Clark and Brennan (1991) refined the idea of common ground by introducing eight constraints affecting grounding: copresence, visibility, audibility, contemporality, simultaneity, sequentiality, reviewability, and revisability. These constraints are based on the fact that common ground takes face-to-face conversation as its basic unit in communication.

            3. COMMUNICATIVE NGOMSL PROCEDURE AND ANALYSIS

            This section presents the procedure for constructing a Communicative NGOMSL model and the analyses of that model in three ways (qualitative evaluation, quantitative evaluation, and mental workload analysis). We also describe important information based on the Communicative NGOMSL analysis results for specific tasks in a text-based communication system.

            3.1. Communicative NGOMSL Procedure

            A Communicative NGOMSL is basically constructed through a top-down and breadth-first expansion of individuals' top-level goals to methods and operators. The procedure is as follows:

            • Step 1: Choose a top-level task goal. The top-level goal is a common task goal that individuals in a group want to accomplish. Individuals expand this goal in a top-down analysis. It is desirable to make the top-level goal as high level as possible to establish a unit-task control structure for a Communicative NGOMSL model. Individuals accomplish this top-level goal by achieving a series of lower level subgoals or tasks.

            • Step 2: Draft methods and tasks required to achieve the top-level goal or the subgoals. One or more methods for accomplishing each goal in a text-based communication system are listed. Each method involves a series of steps, which are arranged in a top-down and breadth-first way. Selection rules provide criteria to choose one among multiple methods for each goal, if applicable.

            • Step 3: Decompose the tasks in each method until individual subtasks are reached. The tasks in each method are decomposed into subtasks until all the subtasks at leaf nodes can be assigned to an individual in the text-based communication system. The operators necessary for completing each task are written down in a sequence. If needed, new operators can be defined by analysts.

            • Step 4: Assign subtasks to each individual. If the previous steps have been done correctly, the next step is to assign subtasks to each individual in the text-based communication system until all the decomposed subtasks are covered by someone.

            • Step 5: Build a Communicative NGOMSL model for a common goal by considering communication time and connecting subtasks among individuals. In a typical situation, an individual performs the subtask at a leaf node and other individuals wait until he or she completes a series of subtasks and completes his or her turn.

            • Step 6: Perform a Communicative NGOMSL analysis for each individual using qualitative evaluation, quantitative evaluation, and mental workload analysis (see section 3.2 for more information). The concept of the grounding process is used to analyze the interface design for specific tasks. Also, the time that an individual will spend waiting for others' responses (termed “communication time” in our study) is considered in estimating execution time.

            • Step 7: Evaluate a text-based communication system for a common goal. The evaluation for a specific task in a text-based communication system is based on the values from the analysis in Step 6. We can obtain information about the relationship between the grounding process and Communicative NGOMSL statements, the ratio of communication time and execution time for each individual, and the balance among individuals for learning time and mental workload (see section 3.2 for more information).

            3.2. Communicative NGOMSL Analysis

            Besides of the properties of NGOMSL, a Communicative NGOMSL analysis involves two key concepts – common ground (the grounding process for achieving a common goal) and communication time. The analysis of a Communicative NGOMSL model is presented in terms of the values and concepts of the qualitative evaluation, the quantitative evaluation, and the mental workload analysis (see Table 1). The analysis results provide some information regarding a common task goal in a text-based communication system. Note that the detailed description of a Communicative NGOMSL analysis is shown through an example case (see section 4).

            Communicative NGOMSL: Development of an Evaluation Method for a Text-Based Communication System

            All authors
            Sangwon Lee & Richard J. Koubek
            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2011.555317
            Published online:
            30 September 2011

            Table 1: Values and Concepts in a Communicative Natural Goals, Operators, Methods, and Selection Rules Language Analysis

            CSVDisplay Table

            Interface design for the grounding process for a common goal

            Common ground is based on four basic ideas (Monk, 2003): (a) conversations are collaborative processes; (b) each person makes the efforts to communicate sufficient information for his or her own purposes; (c) each person also checks the conversation for evidence that the other person is not communicating sufficiently well; and thus (d) each person signals the other person when communication is failing, monitors the conversation for such signals, and tries to fix the situation by taking appropriate actions. Clark's theory (Clark & Schaefer, 1989) also described common ground as follows: A proposition p is only common ground if all persons in communication know p and know that they all know p; common ground plays the role of bridging social and cognitive divides in language. The description of the activity by which persons use and increase common ground and the description of the process of knowing what is known by the others. Communication in a text-based communication can be explained through the grounding process. Matching the statements in a Communicative NGOMSL model with the steps of the grounding process identifies subtasks or design attributes in a system that are directly related to achieving a common group goal. This is useful in designing interfaces for systems that will allow for efficient communication in a group. Consequently, the use of the grounding process allows for diverse and sufficient descriptions of individuals' behaviors in text-based communication.

            Relationship of communication time and execution time

            An individual in a text-based communication system often confronts a situation in which he or she must wait for the other people's responses. The person usually does nothing until the others complete their actions as feedback. However, the existing NGOMSL model does not consider this kind of time because the focus of the model is on an individual's cognitive processing. To resolve this shortcoming, Communicative NGOMSL considers such waiting time as “communication time.” Note that communication time is different from system response time, which refers to the time during which a person is idle while waiting for a system's response. Communication time certainly exists in any text-based communication system, even if the amount of communication time is very low. By considering communication time, we can better describe communication between persons. Like past NGOMSL models, Communicative NGOMSL provides estimations of execution time for tasks on the interface. Communication time leads to more precise predictions of execution time that depend on each individual's situation. Most important, Communicative NGOMSL provides the ratio of communication time to execution time for each person. This ratio needs to be controlled at a similar level across individuals in order to be utilized to develop a text-based communication system where working and resting are properly placed in a sequence of tasks adding to up a common goal.

            Balance among individuals for learning time and mental workload

            Communicative NGOMSL also estimates each individual's learning time for the interface of a text-based communication system and describes mental workload. These two values of a Communicative NGOMSL model are obtained based on the properties of established GOMS techniques. Specifically speaking, the relationship between GOMS models and mental workload has been less clearly understood than learning time (Kieras, 1988). We can consider each individual's mental workload from three viewpoints (Kieras, 1988): (a) the depth of the goal stack as the task is executed, (b) the peak number of chunks that are retained before a Forget, and (c) the number of complex analyst-defined mental operators. For efficient communication, it is necessary to maintain a balance among individuals for learning time and mental workload. Communicative NGOMSL makes it possible to compare persons in terms of these two values. This helps set up tasks leading to the achievement of a common goal, consequently affecting the interface design of a text-based communication system.

            4. APPLICATION OF COMMUNICATIVE NGOMSL—A SAMPLE CASE

            To demonstrate a possible application of Communicative NGOMSL, we use a simple sample case—a virtual text-only chat tool by means of which two persons exchange their addresses in text. A person's contact list is embedded, and the chat window shared with the other person is activated by double-clicking his or her name in the contact list. A Communicative NGOMSL model for this communication is constructed and analyzed next.

            4.1. Top-Level User Goal and Assumptions

            The topmost user goal is to exchange addresses via the text-based communication system. To create a Communicative NGOMSL model, the assumptions made, based on the concepts of common ground (see section 3.2.1), are as follows:

            •

            Person A and Person B know each other.

            •

            Person A and Person B want to know each other's addresses. This goal is accomplished.

            •

            Person A has registered a few contacts, including Person B, in his or her contact list.

            •

            The chat window between Person A and Person B is activated by Person A.

            •

            Person A and Person B share the chat window.

            •

            Person A asks Person B's address first, and then Person B asks Person A's address.

            •

            Communication between Person A and Person B occurs only in text.

            •

            The question for asking the address is “what is your address?” which requires 21 keystrokes including the space bar.

            •

            Typing Person A's address requires 15 keystrokes.

            •

            Typing Person B's address requires 15 keystrokes.

            •

            Person A and Person B each type “okay” as a signal that they have received the other's address.

            •

            Person A and Person B each send their text by pressing the ENTER key after completing it.

            •

            The system response time is 0.

            •

            The typical learning situation is relevant.

            4.2. Communicative NGOMSL Construction

            Communicative NGOMSL modeling for two individuals exchanging addresses through a text-based chat tool is described in Table 2. The construction rules for a Communicative NGOMSL model are based on those for an NGOMSL model. As described in “Method to accomplish goal of exchanging addresses,” the top-level task goal can be achieved by accomplishing the goals of Person A's getting Person B's address and of Person B's getting Person A's address (i.e., in the model, “Method to accomplish goal of Person A's getting Person B's address” and “Method to accomplish goal of Person B's getting Person A's address”). Each of these goals can be completed by performing tasks in a series of steps. Some of the steps include lower level goals (i.e., Step 1, Step 2, and Step 3 in “Method to accomplish goal of Person A's getting Person B's address”). Again, the methods to achieve these lower subgoals are described (i.e., “Method to accomplish goal of Person A's finding Person B,” “Method to accomplish goal of Person A' asking Person B's address,” and “Method to accomplish goal of Person B's replying with his or her address”). The tasks included in each method are decomposed until individual subtasks at the leaf nodes are reached. Each subtask is assigned to Person A or Person B. In the Communicative NGOMSL model, the notations A and B in Table 2 refer to the methods consisting of the subtasks that Person A and Person B are in charge of, respectively. The Communicative NGOMSL statements are written down in a top-down and breadth-first expansion sequence. The numbers of Communicative NGOMSL statements associated with Person A and Person B are 33 and 26, respectively. To help analyze the Communicative NGOMSL model, we denote communication time, external operator, and analyst-defined mental operator in Table 2.

            4.3. Communicative NGOMSL Analysis

            In analyzing the aforementioned Communicative NGOMSL model, we describe at which levels the goals (subgoals), the methods, and the operators are found; which tasks correspond to the grounding process step; and which operators are executed by Person A and Person B, taking communication time into account.

            Qualitative evaluation: Description of communication with grounding process

            The text-based chat tool used by two individuals to exchange their addresses can be evaluated by relating the Communicative NGOMSL model of it to the grounding process. Here, several checks involving the established qualitative properties (naturalness, completeness, cleanliness, consistency, and efficiency) of an NGOMSL model are left undone because the case study is based on a dummy system. The Communicative NGOMSL statements corresponding to each step in the grounding process are presented in Tables 3 and 4. The completion of Phase 1 and Phase 2 means that the exchange of addresses between Person A and Person B is complete.

            Quantitative evaluation: Prediction of human performance with communication time

            In the quantitative evaluation of the text-based communication system with Communicative NGOMSL, execution time (for each individual and for the whole task group) and learning time (for each individual) are estimated, taking communication time into account. Execution time can be calculated by summing “NGOMSL statement time,” “Primitive external operator time,” “Analyst-defined mental operator time,” “System response time,” and “Communication time.” Also, learning time can be estimated by adding “NGOMSL method learning time” and “LTM item learning time” together.

            Mental workload analysis

            Mental workload can be evaluated for each individual. Person A's mental workload is the same as that of Person B. For both Person A and Person B, the depth of the goal stack as the task is executed is 5 (see Tables 2 and 3). Also, the peak number of chunks that are retained before a Forget is 4. This is associated with sending a text to a Person by pressing ENTER after completing it (see “Estimating Learning Time for Task Goal” in Table 5). Finally, the number of complex analyst-defined mental operators for both Person A and Person B is 4. These operators are related to recognizing and understanding the other's responses.

            4.4. Summary and Implications

            Our Communicative NGOMSL model for exchanging addresses between two persons by means of a virtual text-based communication system was constructed based on the procedure we described in section 3.1 and was analyzed in terms of the grounding process, communication/execution/learning time, and mental workload. The qualitative evaluation of the Communicative NGOMSL model matched the methods (or operators) with the grounding process steps. Through the application of the grounding concept to the text-based communication system, we determined which tasks would be directly associated with the grounding process (utterance, understanding of utterance, evidence of understanding sufficient for current purpose, understanding of evidence of understanding sufficient for current purpose, and grounding criterion; see Tables 3 and 4). In Phase 1, where Person A is a speaker and Person B is an addressee, Person A asks the question “what is your address?” and receives Person B's response to this question. This procedure can be linked to the steps in the grounding process. For example, Step 2 (“Type question to ask Person B's address”) and Step 3 (“Retain that command is ENTER, and accomplish goal of issuing a command”) in “Method to accomplish goal of Person A's asking Person B's address” are denoted as an “utterance” of the grounding process. Other steps in the grounding process can be matched with some Communicative NGOMSL statements. As mentioned in section 3.2.1, the interface design related to such a subtask is important in achieving the common group task, and thus it is necessary to focus on that interface in developing the communication system, for example, providing a shortcut for the question “what is your address?” and considering adding a SEND command to allow the user to more efficiently send a message.

            The results of the quantitative evaluation (communication time, execution time, and learning time) and the mental workload analysis (the depth of the goal stack as the task is executed, the peak number of chunks that are retained before a Forget, the number of complex analyst-defined mental operators) are presented in Tables 6 and 7. For the group task of exchanging addresses between two persons via the text-based communication system, execution times, considering communication time, for Person A and Person B are almost the same. However, execution time (without considering communication time) per the unit communication time of Person A is greater than that of Person B. Considering that Person A and Person B are not different with respect to execution time (with considering communication time) and communication time is an individual's time waiting without executing a subtask, it is important to keep the ratio of communication time to execution time (without considering communication time) of the individuals at a similar level. Given the same levels of execution time considering communication time, efforts are needed to reduce the execution time or increase the communication time of Person A or to increase the execution time or reduce the communication time of Person B. In addition, the mental workloads are the same but learning times are different for the individuals using the text-based chat tool. As described in section 3.2.3, it is necessary to balance Person A and Person B in terms of learning time and mental workload. Given the same mental workload, the focus in the sample case is on learning time. The learning time of Person A is more than 4 times that of Person B. This means that Person A needs more training to learn methods to achieve the common goal than does Person B. Thus, the interface of the communication system and the group task should be designed to eliminate the differential in learning times—to distribute learning times evenly across individuals.

            Communicative NGOMSL: Development of an Evaluation Method for a Text-Based Communication System

            All authors
            Sangwon Lee & Richard J. Koubek
            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2011.555317
            Published online:
            30 September 2011

            Table 6: Communication Time and Execution Time

            CSVDisplay Table

            Communicative NGOMSL: Development of an Evaluation Method for a Text-Based Communication System

            All authors
            Sangwon Lee & Richard J. Koubek
            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2011.555317
            Published online:

            5. DISCUSSION AND CONCLUSION

            This study proposed Communicative NGOMSL, an extension of NGOMSL, to accommodate the modeling of text-based communication among two or more persons. Communicative NGOMSL basically covers all the properties of NGOMSL in qualitative evaluation, quantitative evaluation, and mental workload analysis. The key concepts in Communicative NGOMSL are common ground (the grounding process) and communication time. In developing Communicative NGOMSL, we considered the interdependence of the way individuals communicate in the social environment (in our study, communication to reach a common goal between two individuals who know each other well) and the communication methods used (in our study, text-based communication via a chat tool; Grudin, 1988), as well as the difficulty of applying Clark's contribution theory of discourse (common ground; Clark & Schaefer, 1989) as an analytic framework to CSCW in a concrete setting (Koschmann & LeBaron, 2003). For these reasons, it was necessary to limit the application domain of Communicative NGOMSL to a text-based communication system. The sample case (i.e., the Communicative NGOMSL model for exchanging the addresses of two individuals in the virtual system) showed that connecting Communicative NGOMSL statements with the grounding process would lead to easier application of common ground in a text-based communication system. Besides the analysis using the established techniques of NGOMSL, the Communicative NGOMSL analysis involving the grounding process and communication time provides information for designers and developers of text-based communication systems: (a) the relationship between the grounding process and Communicative NGOMSL statements, (b) the ratio of communication time to execution time (without considering communication time) for each individual, and (c) the balance among individuals in terms of learning time and mental workload. That is, designers and developers need to invest more effort in designing interfaces that are directly related to the grounding process in communication, to control the ratio of communication time to execution time (without considering communication time) for persons at a similar level, and to maintain a balance among individuals in a group in terms of learning time and mental workload. The new indexes related to these would be the contribution of Communicative NGOMSL to the evaluation of text-based communication systems, although Communicative NGOMSL has no benefit over GOMS techniques in terms of time or cost.

            Further studies are needed to address the limitations of this study. First, it is necessary to apply the model to a real text-based communication system to better demonstrate the contributions of Communicative NGOMSL. In this study, the construction and the analysis of Communicative NGOMSL were illuminated through a virtual text-based chat tool, and certain assumptions were made. This was to introduce a Communicative NGOMSL model through a simple sample case clearly and easily. It would be useful and instructive to add a few examples of the practical value a Communicative NGOMSL model might have in terms of real-world system design. For example, further studies can examine whether the approach can be scaled up to provide insight into more realistic communication tasks. Very often, users have a tendency to use shorthand text (e.g., “Whatz ur address?” for “What is your address?”). Using such shorthand texts in a conversation can be connected to each individual's learning time and mental workload. In a Communicative NGOMSL model, the association between normal texts and shorthand texts can be considered a long-term memory item to be learned by each individual, affecting his or her mental workload and the performance times for execution and communication. Also, real systems can be analyzed according to the established qualitative properties (naturalness, completeness, cleanliness, consistency, and efficiency) and the selection rules that were not covered in the evaluation of our sample case.

            Second, this study did not consider the constraints of grounding in developing Communicative NGOMSL. According to Clark and Schaefer (1989) and McCarthy et al. (1991), these constraints include copresence, visibility, audibility, contemporality, simultaneity, sequentiality, reviewability, and revisability. Clark and Schaefer predicted that common ground would be more difficult to establish when such constraints were not available, and McCarthy et al. provided evidence for Clark and Schaefer's expectation through an experiment with two versions of a communication system (i.e., a private condition and a public condition). Considering the features of the system and the task and the properties of NGOMSL, the sample case inherently covers the characteristics of visibility, contemporality, simultaneity, and sequentiality but does not include those of audibility, reviewability, and revisability. By relating the grounding constraints to user performance in a real text-based communication system, we can better analyze and interpret a Communicative NGOMSL model for that system, especially in terms of qualitative evaluation. For example, we can consider the conversation occurring in parallel (opposite to sequentiality) in a text-based communication system. If individuals know their common task goal and a person can send the text “Let us exchange addresses” to the other person, typing and sending the address of each individual to the other can occur at the same time. Moreover, we can think that a person get another question texted to the other person in advance while he or she is typing. The communication time in such a case can be less than that of our sample case. To provide more information for a system, the communication in parallel should be considered and expressed in a Communicative NGOMSL model.

            Third, Communicative NGOMSL needs to be generalized or modified so that it can be applied to other types of CMC systems. As seen in the sample case, Communicative NGOMSL is concerned with modeling a group task in a text-based communication system. The application of Communicative NGOMSL is mainly based on the inherent characteristics of NGOMSL and common ground: NGOMSL has been developed to evaluate computerized systems using a keyboard or a mouse as an input device, and common ground basically originates from face-to-face conversation (which supports a basis of synchronicity of text-based communication via a chat tool) for a common goal. To evaluate other CMC systems with different features in time and space, researchers should obtain time estimates for using input devices other than a keyboard and a mouse. It is necessary to consider new communication systems or devices, like the speech communication using an intercom and an external radio channel in Kieras and Santoro (2004), in developing a more general Communicative NGOMSL model. Also, the concept of common ground needs to be modified for specific communication environments. For example, unlike a text-based chat tool, an e-mail system or a message board is an asynchronous application, which requires modification of the concepts of the grounding process in Communicative NGOMSL.

            Last, further studies need to broaden Communicative NGOMSL to various CMC situations by taking a sociopsychological approach. The computer-mediated format has an effect on many different aspects of the interaction between individuals and systems. In past studies, these aspects have included social presence (e.g., Ning Shen & Khalifa, 2008), impression formation (e.g., Hancock & Dunham, 2001; Utz, 2010), deception (e.g., Birnholtz, Guillory, Hancock, & Bazarova, 2010; Carlson, George, Burgoon, Adkins, & White, 2004), group dynamics (e.g., Hettinger, 1995; Leshed et al., 2009), disinhibition (e.g., Joinson, 1998; Suler, 2004), and relationship formation (e.g., McKenna & Bargh, 2000; Rabby & Walther, 2003). The effects of CMC on these factors depend on contexts, formats, and programs in CMC systems. It is necessary to approach this issue from social and psychological viewpoints and, more specifically, develop Communicative NGOMSL so that it can evaluate CMC systems (including text-based communication systems) in terms of their sociopsychological aspects. However, much effort will be required to connect Communicative MGOMSL to sociopsychological features, in that the existing GOMS properties are based on a user's expertise (without any interruption) with a system and a task and thus they do not consider social or psychological aspects. In fact, this can cause the difficulty of validating our demonstration by an actual study to show how well user performance matches that predicted by our proposed method. As previously mentioned, Communicative NGOMSL inherently has the assumptions and the properties of NGOMSL—predefined time estimates for operators, based on expertise without any flexibility in performance or time spent in correcting errors. That is, the quantitative evaluation data provided in a Communicative NGOMSL analysis are derived from these theoretical predictions. Due to these features of Communicative NGOMSL, the validation using actual user data cannot be easily achieved. Kieras and Santoro (2004) stated that psychological issues and interruptability in real situations are not properly considered in GOMS-related techniques evaluating large and complex systems involving team of humans. This issue needs to be examined more deeply in future work.

            Method to accomplish goal of exchanging addressesA, B
             Step 1. Accomplish goal of Person A's getting Person B's address 
             Step 2. Accomplish goal of Person B's getting Person A's address 
             Step 3. Return with goal accomplished 
            Method to accomplish goal of Person A's getting Person B's addressA
             Step 1. Accomplish goal of Person A's finding Person B 
             Step 2. Accomplish goal of Person A's asking Person B's address 
             Step 3. Accomplish goal of Person B's replying with his/her address*
             Step 4. Check Person B's address+
             Step 5. Type “okay”∧
             Step 6. Wait until Person B checks “okay”*, +
             Step 7. Return with goal accomplished 
            Method to accomplish goal of Person B's getting Person A's addressB
             Step 1. Accomplish goal of Person B's asking Person A's address 
             Step 2. Accomplish goal of Person A's replying with his/her address*
             Step 3. Check Person A's address+
             Step 4. Type “okay”∧
             Step 5. Wait until Person A check “okay”*, +
             Step 6. Return with goal accomplished 
            Method to accomplish goal of Person A's finding Person BA
             Step 1. Retrieve from LTM Person B's name, and retain it 
             Step 2. Recall Person B's name, and move cursor to it∧
             Step 3. Double-click mouse button∧
             Step 4. Forget Person B's name, and return with goal accomplished 
            Method to accomplish goal of Person A's asking Person B's addressA
             Step 1. Home to hand to keyboard∧
             Step 2. Type question to ask Person B's address∧
             Step 3. Retain that command is SEND, and accomplish goal of issuing SEND command 
             Step 4. Return with goal accomplished 
            Method to accomplish goal of Person B's replying with his/her addressA
             Step 1. Check Person A's question+
             Step 2. Retrieve from LTM Person B's address and retain it 
             Step 3. Recall Person B's address, and type it∧
             Step 4. Recall Person B's address, and verify that it is correct+
             Step 5. Retain that command is SEND, and accomplish goal of issuing SEND command 
             Step 6. Forget Person B's address, and return with goal accomplished 
            Method to accomplish goal of Person B's asking Person A's addressB
             Step 1. Type question to ask Person A's address∧
             Step 2. Retain that command is SEND, and accomplish goal of issuing SEND command 
             Step 3. Return with goal accomplished 
            Method to accomplish goal of Person A's replying with his/her addressB
             Step 1. Check Person B's question+
             Step 2. Retrieve from LTM Person A's address and retain Person A's address 
             Step 3. Recall Person A's address, and type it∧
             Step 4. Recall Person A's address, and verify that it is correct+
             Step 5. Retain that command is SEND, and accomplish goal of issuing SEND command 
             Step 6. Forget Person A's address, and return with goal accomplished 
            Method to accomplish goal of issuing SEND commandA, B
             Step 1. Recall command name and retain it 
             Step 2. Press the button ENTER∧
             Step 3. Forget command name, and return with goal accomplished 
            Note. A = methods (tasks) for Person A; B = methods (tasks) for Person B; * = Communication time; ∧ = external operator; + = analyst-defined mental operator; LTM = long-term memory.
            Table 3: Communicative Natural Goals, Operators, Methods, and Selection Rules Language Analysis for Two Individuals' Exchanging Addresses (color table available online)
            Table 4: Description of Communication With Grounding Process
             
            Phase 1: Person A as a Speaker and Person B as an Addressee
            • Utterance, u
            Method to accomplish goal of Person A's asking Person B's address
             Step 2. Type question to ask Person B's address
             Step 3. Retain that command is SEND, and accomplish goal of issuing SEND command
            - Person A types “what is your address?” for Person B to consider. There is a common ground already existing between them in order to present this question by typing.
            • Understanding of utterance, u'
            Method to accomplish goal of Person B's replying with his/her address
             Step 1. Check Person A's question
            - Person B attempts to infer the import of Person A's question, interpreting and understanding it.
            • Evidence of understanding sufficient for current purpose, e
            Method to accomplish goal of Person B's replying with his/her address
             Step 3. Recall Person B's address, and type it
             Step 4. Recall Person B's address, and verify that it is correct
             Step 5. Retain that command is SEND, and accomplish goal of issuing SEND command
            - Person B provides an evidence of sufficient understanding of Person A's question by typing Person B's address.
            • Understanding of evidence of understanding sufficient for current purposes, e′
            Method to accomplish goal of Person A's getting Person B's address
             Step 4. Check Person B's address
             Step 5. Type “okay”
            - Person A judges that Person B has understood Person A's utterance sufficient for exchanging addresses, and signals to Person B that Person A understands Person B.
            • Grounding criterion, c
            Method to accomplish goal of Person A's getting Person B's address
             Step 6. Check “okay” (Person B)
            Method to accomplish goal of exchanging addresses
             Step 1. Accomplish goal of Person A's getting Person B's address
            - Person A gets Person B's address. This meets the ground criteria.
            Phase 2: Person B as a Speaker and Person A as an Addressee
            • Utterance, u
            Method to accomplish goal of Person B's asking Person A's address
             Step 1. Type question to ask Person A's address
             Step 2. Retain that command is SEND, and accomplish goal of issuing SEND command
            - Person B types “what is your address?” for Person A to consider. There is a common ground already existing between them in order to present this question by typing.
            • Understanding of utterance, u′
            Method to accomplish goal of Person A's replying with his/her address
             Step 1. Check Person B's question
            - Person A attempts to infer the import of Person B's question, interpreting and understanding it.
            • Evidence of understanding sufficient for current purpose, e
            Method to accomplish goal of Person A's replying with his/her address
             Step 3. Recall Person A's address, and type it
             Step 4. Recall Person A's address, and verify that it is correct
             Step 5. Retain that command is SEND, and accomplish goal of issuing SEND command
            - Person A provides an evidence of sufficient understanding of Person B's question by typing Person A's address.
            • Understanding of evidence of understanding sufficient for current purposes, e′
            Method to accomplish goal of Person B's getting Person A's address
             Step 3. Check Person A's address
             Step 4. Type “okay”
            - Person B judges that Person A has understood Person B's utterance sufficient for exchanging addresses, and signals to Person A that Person B understands Person A.
            • Grounding criterion, c
            Method to accomplish goal of Person B's getting Person A's address
             Step 5. Check “okay” (Person A)
            Method to accomplish goal of exchanging addresses
             Step 2. Accomplish goal of Person B's getting Person A's address
            - Person B gets Person A's address. This meets the ground criteria. Now, exchanging the addresses between Person A and Person B is completed.
            Table 5: Prediction of Human Performance With Communication Time
             
            Estimating Execution Time for Task Goal
            Person A
            NGOMSL statement time
             = 0.1 s * (Number of NGOMSL statements executed by Person A) = 0.1 s * 33 = 3.3 s
            The primitive external operator times are as follows (Card et al., 1983): 0.28 for a keystroke; 0.1 s for a mouse button press or release; 1.1 s for a mouse move; 0.4 s to home the hand to a keyboard or a mouse
            Primitive external operator time
             = (Total of times for external operators of Person A) = 0.28*4 + 1.1 + 0.2 + 0.4 + 0.28*21 + 0.28*15 + 0.28 = 13.18 s
            Time of each analyst-defined mental operator is 1.35 s (Card et al., 1983).
            Analyst-defined mental operator time
             = (Total of times for mental operators of Person A defined by an analyst) = 1.35 s * 4 = 5.4 s
            By the assumption, System response time = 0
            Communication time is the total waiting time for the other's responses. Person A's waiting times correspond to several methods or operators executed by Person B. That is, communication time of Person A can be obtained by calculating the estimated execution time for Person B during Person A's waiting for Person B's responses.
            Communication time of Person A
             = (Total waiting time for Person B's responses)
             = (0.1*7 + 1.35 + 0.28*15 + 1.35) + (0.1*1 + 1.35) + (0.1*4 + 0.28*21) + (0.1*2 + 1.35 + 0.28*4) + (0.1*4 + 0.28)
             = 18.68 s
            Thus,
            Execution time of Person A (when not considering communication time)
             = (NGOMSL statement time) + (Primitive external operator time) + (Analyst-defined mental operator time) + (System response time)
             = 3.3 + 13.18 + 5.4 + 0 = 21.88 s
            Execution time of Person A (when considering communication time)
             = (NGOMSL statement time) + (Primitive external operator time) + (Analyst-defined mental operator time) + (System response time)
            + (Communication time)
             = 3.3 + 13.18 + 5.4 + 0 + 18.68 = 40.56 s
            Person B
            NGOMSL statement time
             = 0.1 s * (Number of NGOMSL statements executed by Person B) = 0.1 s * 26 = 2.6 s
            Primitive external operator time
             = (Total of times for external operators of Person B) = 0.28*4 + 0.28*15 + 0.28*21 + 0.28 = 11.48 s
            Analyst-defined mental operator time
             = (Total of times for mental operators of Person B defined by an analyst) = 1.35 s * 4 = 5.4 s
            System response time = 0
            Communication time
             = (Total waiting time for Person B's responses)
             = (0.1*5 + 1.1 + 0.2) + (0.1*5 + 0.4 + 0.28*21) + (0.1*2 + 1.35 + 0.28*4) + (0.1*7 + 1.35 + 0.28*15 + 1.35) + (0.1*1 + 1.35)
             + (0.1*4 + 0.28)
             = 20.98 s
            Thus,
            Execution time of Person B (when not considering communication time)
             = (NGOMSL statements time) + (Primitive external operator time) + (Analyst-defined mental operator time) + (System response time)
             = 2.6 + 11.48 + 5.4 + 0 = 19.48 s
            Execution time of Person B (when considering communication time)
             = (NGOMSL statements time) + (Primitive external operator time) + (Analyst-defined mental operator time) + (System response time)
             + (Communication time)
             = 2.6 + 11.48 + 5.4 + 0 + 20.98 = 40.46 s
            Total – Analysis of the whole task
            The whole task (exchanging address between Person A and Person B) in a text-based communication system is analyzed. This analysis is based on the constructed Communicative NGOMSL (see Table 1). Here, the methods or the operators in the model are not assigned to Person A or Person B by who executes them because the analysis of the whole task considers Person A and Person B together in one shared communication system.
            NGOMSL statement time
             = 0.1 s * (Number of NGOMSL statements executed) = 0.1 s * 51 = 5.1 s
            Primitive external operator time
             = (Total of times for external operators) = 13.18 + 11.48 = 24.66 s
            Analyst-defined mental operator time
             = (Total of times for mental operators defined by an analyst) = 1.35 s * 8 = 10.8 s
            System response time = 0
            Thus,
            Execution time
             = (NGOMSL statements time) + (Primitive external operator time) + (Analyst-defined mental operator time) + (System response time)
             = 5.1 + 24.66 + 10.8 + 0 = 40.56 s
            Estimating Learning Time for Task Goal
            Person A
            The learning time parameter is 17 s for a typical learning situation (Kieras, 1996). Suppose that the method to accomplish the goal of Person A's finding Person B needs to be learned. In this case, the number of NGOMSL statements to be learned by Person A is 5.
            NGOMSL method learning time of Person A
             = 17 s * (Number of NGOMSL statements to be learned by Person A) = 17 s * 5 = 85 s
            The to-send-text association for a command is “send a text is press Enter key”. Then,
            (send a text)(to a Person) = 2 chunk
            (press Enter key) = 1 chunk
            Association between the two = 1 chunk
            LTM item learning time of Person A
             = 6 s * (Number of LTM chunks to be learned by Person A) = 6 s * 4 = 24 s
            Thus,
            Pure procedure learning time of Person A
             = (NGOMSL method learning time) + (LTM item learning time) = 85 + 24 = 109 s
            Person B
            NGOMSL method learning time of Person B
             = 17 s * (Number of NGOMSL statements to be learned by Person B) = 17 s * 0 = 0 s
            LTM item learning time
             = 6 s * (Number of LTM chunks to be learned by Person B) = 6 s * 4 = 24 s
            Thus,
            Pure Procedure Learning Time
             = (NGOMSL method learning time) + (LTM item learning time) = 0 + 24 = 24 s
            Note. NGOMSL = Natural Goals, Operators, Methods, and Selection Rules Language; LTM = long-term memory.

                Ratio of Communication
             Communication TimeNot Considering Communication TimeConsidering Communication TimeTime to Execution Time (not Considering Communication Time)
            Person A18.68 s21.88 s40.56 s18.68 : 21.88 ≈ 1 : 1.17
            Person B20.98 s19.48 s40.46 s20.98 : 19.48 ≈ 1 : 0.93
